message_1: A math student wants to know how many ways to choose a committee of 3 students from a group of 7 students. What is the number of combinations possible using binomial coefficients?
message_2:
To find the number of combinations possible for choosing a committee of 3 students from a group of 7 students, we can use the binomial coefficient formula, which is:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where C(n, k) represents the number of combinations, n is the total number of students, and k is the number of students to be chosen for the committee.

In this case, n = 7 and k = 3. So, we have:

C(7, 3) = 7! / (3!(7-3)!)

C(7, 3) = 7! / (3!4!)

C(7, 3) = (7 × 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((3 × 2 × 1)(4 × 3 × 2 × 1))

C(7, 3) = (7 × 6 × 5) / (3 × 2 × 1)

C(7, 3) = 210 / 6

C(7, 3) = 35

So, there are 35 different ways to choose a committee of 3 students from a group of 7 students.
